title: Brontë Country
author: Emily, Charlotte and Anne Brontë
bodyText: Among the most famous literary families the Brontë sisters wrote some of the most beloved works in literature. The parsonage where they lived with their father and brother is now a museum. The family, with the exception of Anne is buried in the church's vault. The Brontë Waterfall nearby was a favorite site of the sisters.

title: A Romance of Exmoor
author: Richard Doddridge Blackmore
bodyText: Porlock and Dulverton are the center of Lorna Doone Country. The Ship Inn in Portlock was well known to Coleridge, Wordsworth and Southery.

title: The Bard of Stratford-upon-Avon
book: Hamlet, Romeo and Juliet, The Taming of the Shrew ...
author: William Shakespeare
bodyText: Widely believed to be the greatest writer in the English language, William Shakespeare wrote some 39 plays, 154 sonnets and three long narrative poems. The building believed to be his birthplace is a museum. His wife Anne Hathaway's home is nearby.

title: William Wordsworth's home
book: The Prelude, Ode: Intimations of Immortality, Ode to Duty, My Heart Leaps Up
author: William Wordsworth
bodyText: Wordsworth wrote much of the poetry for which he is known as Dove Cottage near Grasmere. He lived here for 8 years with his sister, from 1799 to 1808.

title: Count Dracula Arrives in England
author: Bram Stoker
bodyText: The ruins of Whitby Abbey stand on the cliff of above the town of Whitby overlooking the North Sea. Inspired by its gothic atmosphere when he visited in 1890, Bram Stocker set parts of his novel around the area. His Count Dracula comes to Whitby when he first arrives in England.

title: London's Writers' Block
author: Henry James, Erskine Childers, T. S. Eliot, Somerset Maugham, Ian Fleming, George Elliot, Bram Stoker, Elizabeth Gaskell...
bodyText: This historic London 2-block street has been home to numerous authors. The Carlyle Mansions (number 24) has been nicknamed the 'Writers’ Block,' as it has been home to Henry James, Erskine Childers, T. S. Eliot, Somerset Maugham, Ian Fleming and other noted authors. Other authors have lived near by. George Elliot spent the last three weeks of her life at number 4. Bram Stoker lived at number 27. And Elizabeth Gaskell was born at number 93.

title: Romance in the English Civil War
author: Sir Walter Scott
bodyText: Now a ruins, this 11th-century castle, became the setting of one of Sir Walter Scott's Waverley novels (a series that includes Ivanhoe).

title: Visit's Gaskell's Cranford
author: Elizabeth Gaskell
bodyText: Elizabeth Gaskell's charming portrait of village life in the 19th century was based on her own childhood home of Knutsford.

title: Elizabeth Gaskell's Home
book: Mary Barton, North and South, Cranford, Wives and Daughters
author: Elizabeth Gaskell
bodyText: Gaskell's historic home was restored in 2014. It is now a museum to the author and her times.

title: Jane Austen's Home
book: Pride and Prejudice, Sense and Sensibility, Emma, Persuasion
author: Jane Austen
bodyText: Jane Austen spent the last eight years of her life at this home that is now a museum.

title: Tolkien's Old Forest
author: J.R.R. Tolkien
bodyText: Moseley Bog is a woodland park in Moseley near Birmingham. J.R.R. Tolkien lived nearby as a boy. It is believed to have inspired the Old Forest in Middle Earth.

title: Birthplace of Charles Dickens
book: Great Expectations, David Copperfield, Oliver Twist, A Tale of Two Cities ...
author: Charles Dickens
bodyText: The house where the famed novelist was born is now a museum. It is furnished in the Regency style popular at the time of his birth iin 1812.

title: Hardy's Cottage
book: Far from the Madding Crowd, The Mayor of Casterbridge, Tess of the d'Urbervilles, and Jude the Obscure
author: Thomas Hardy
bodyText: Thomas Hardy was born in a cottage outside Dorchester. He would later fictionalize Dorchester as the town of Casterbridge in his novel 'The Mayor of Casterbridge.' Hardy set most of his writing in a county he called Wessex. Hardy's Wessex encompassed the counties of Dorset, Wiltshire, Somerset, Devon, Hampshire and much of Berkshire.

title: Jamaica Inn
author: Daphne du Maurier
bodyText: Daphne du Maurier made this inn from 1750 famous in her 1936 novel of the same name. The inn has a historical association with smuggling.

title: Curious Affairs in Swindon
book: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time and The Eyre Affair
author: Mark Haddon and Jasper Fforde
bodyText: Christopher, the main character in Mark Haddon's 'The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time,' lives in Swindon. Swindon is also the location of Jasper Fforde's fantastical alternative 1985 of The Eyre Affair. The town planning office named streets in town after Fforde's characters. Look out for Thursday Street, Mycroft Road and Havisham Drive.

title: Where did Louisa Musgrove fall?
author: Jane Austen
bodyText: Jane Austen sent her characters in her novel 'Persuasion' to Lyme to visit friends. It is there that the character Louisa Musgrove is injured after a fall at The Cobb.

title: Deep in the Hundred Acre Wood
book: Winnie-the-Pooh and The House at Pooh Corner
author: A.A. Milne
townName: Five Hundred Acre Wood, Ashdown Forest, Hartfield, East Sussex
bodyText: From A.A. Milne's country home near Hartfield, the nearby Five Hundred Acre Wood would serve as the inspiration for the fictional wood inhabited by Winnie the Pooh and his friends. Many features from the stories can be found in this forest. An interpretive trail provides insights into this classic story.
